section.title: Introduction

note.para: The &sr; RPM distribution does not include support for PETSc. PETSc support is available only to the &sr; source code distribution. The PETSc library adds additional solvers to &sr;'s SolveMatrix module. See for details.

section.para: Root privileges are required to install &sr;. The system administrator can install &sr; if you don't have root privileges.

RPM installation consists of the following steps:
Downloading the &sr; RPM distribution and &sr;'s sample data sets.
Installing &sr; using the rpm command.
Installing &sr;'s sample data sets.
Installing &sr;'s documentation.

section.title: Downloading
section.para:
From SCI's software archive page download the following files:
Either &sr;-x.x.x-mdk9.0.i586.rpm for Mandrake 9 systems or &sr;-x.x.x-rh8.0.i386.rpm for Redhat 8 systems.
DataSets.x.x.x.tar.gz too.
docs.x.x.x.tar.gz

section.title: Installing
section.para: Open a shell terminal (e.g. xterm) and enter the command su to become the root user (superuser). The su command will prompt for root's password. If you do not have root access then ask the system administrator to install the RPM.

Now cd to the directory where &sr; was downloaded and type:
rpm -ivh &sr;-x.x.x-mdk9.0.i586.rpm
for Mandrake 9 systems and
rpm -ivh &sr;-x.x.x-rh8.0.i386.rpm
for Red Hat 8 systems. The RPM should take approximately one minute to install.
Type exit to leave the root account.

section.title: Installing &sr;'s Sample Data Sets
section.para: The following procedure installs the sample data sets in the directory /usr/local. It assumes you have root privileges.

Use the su command to become the root user. Then Cd to the directory containing the compressed data sets tarball and type:
gunzip -c DataSets.x.x.x.tar.gz | (cd /usr/local && tar xf -)
This will create /usr/local/&sr;Data, the sample data sets directory. Type exit to exit the root account.

section.title: Installing &sr;'s Documentation
section.para: The following procedure installs the documentation in the directory /usr/local

Use the su command to become the root user. Then Cd to the directory containing the compressed documentation tarball and type:
gunzip -c docs.x.x.x.tar.gz | (cd /usr/local && tar xf -)
This will create /usr/local/&sr;Docs, the &sr; documentation directory. Type exit to exit the root account.
Point a browser at /usr/local/&sr;Docs/doc/index.html to view &sr;'s online documentation.
